summary: A study found that 26.5% of U.S. respondents scaled back their use of routine medical care since the economic recession, due in part to the uninsurance rate.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for Sept. 3, 2010.

headline: Mets 4, Braves 2
summary: The Mets salvaged one victory out of their four-game series against the Braves, winning 4-2 on Thursday night, but starter Johan Santana left the game with an injury.

headline: Kan, Ozawa in Tight Race
summary: With less than two weeks until the ruling Democratic Party of Japan's leadership election, local polls show that Prime Minister Naoto Kan and challenger Ichiro Ozawa are locked in a tight race to win support from their own party members.

headline: Google Settles Lawsuit for $8.5 Million
summary: Google has agreed to pay $8.5 million to settle a private class-action lawsuit that alleged its Buzz social networking service violated users' privacy.

headline: Fury Over Public PensionsSparks Disclosure Lawsuits
summary: Several state and local retirement funds have balked at disclosing the pensions of individual government workers, triggering lawsuits that claim taxpayers have the right to such information.

headline: Enron's Skilling Denied Bail
summary: A federal appellate court judge turned down former Enron President Jeffrey Skilling's request for bail pending the continuing judicial review of his 2006 conspiracy and fraud conviction.

headline: Hurricane Earl Moves Up East Coast
summary: Rain and winds from a weaker-than-forecast Hurricane Earl hit the U.S. East Coast Friday.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 3
summary: In Friday's pictures, Hurricane Earl weakens around North Carolina, British Prime Minister David Cameron shows off his daughter, a new platform fire in the Gulf of Mexico and more.

headline: U.S. Open: Day Five Photos
summary: Britain's Andy Murray defeats Jamaica's Dustin Brown, U.S. teen Ryan Harrison loses a heartbreaker and Hurricane Earl delays matches.

headline: Un-Kosher Brunch
summary: Traif, located in a Hasidic neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, uses pork and shellfish as a starting point. But the restaurant has a few brunch items that could pass rabbinical muster.

headline: U.S. Private Sector Adds 67,000 Jobs
summary: The U.S. economy lost 54,000 jobs in August as census workers continued to exit payrolls, but the private sector added 67,000 jobs. The unemployment rate rose to 9.6%.

headline: A Shapely Visitor From Planet Maserati
summary: Curvaceous, spacious and (kind of) fast, the GranTurismo Convertible has an otherworldly allure, says the Journal's Dan Neil.

headline: U.S. Reopens More of the Gulf to Fishing
summary: An additional 3,114 square miles of the Gulf of Mexico off the western Florida panhandle was reopened to commercial and recreational fishing.

headline: Gold Prices Ease Back
summary: Gold futures lost ground as a stronger-than-expected U.S. jobs report dulled some of the metal's safe-haven allure, but a weaker dollar checked those losses.

headline: The Short List
summary: Helen Mirren in "Prime Suspect," new Bob Dylan book; Al Qaeda; Buffalo Wings annd more in a selected guide to this week's arts and entertainment.

headline: Service Data Pressure Crude
summary: Crude futures ended lower after a report showed growth in the U.S. service sector slowed last month.

headline: Goldcorp to Buy Andean
summary: Canadian miner Goldcorp said it had reached a deal to buy Andean Resources in a deal that values the gold company at around $3.42 billion.

headline: BP Removes Blowout Preventer
summary: BP removed a damaged blowout preventer from the well that unleashed the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, marking a step forward in its quest to bring the well to its final demise.

headline: Europe's Online Fashion Evolution
summary: Is online fashion retailing starting to come of age in Europe?

headline: Fourth Man in Canada Terror Probe Is Freed
summary: A man who was under investigation in a Canadian terrorism probe was granted bail Friday on domestic-violence charges and released by police without being charged with terrorism-related offenses.

headline: IEA Sees OPEC Sway Growing
summary: The global dependency on the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for oil will rise as production by non-OPEC nations falls.

headline: BP Provides Lessons Learned From Spill
summary: BP disclosed various lessons and capabilities built from trouble-shooting the big oil spill in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico.

headline: U.S. Data Gives European Stocks End-Of-Week Bump
summary: European stocks rallied in the wake of better-than-expected U.S. employment data, contributing to a strong start for September.

headline: Boeing Has No Plans to Finance 787 Deliveries for 2011
summary: Boeing Co. doesn't plan to finance any of the 787 aircraft due for delivery next year, while one of its largest customers said it needs more clarity on the final delivery schedule before it can approach lenders.

headline: Jobs Report Takes Edge Off Market Fears
summary: Stocks and other growth-sensitive markets, including the euro, got the best news they've had for some time with Friday's better-than-expected U.S. payrolls report.

headline: New York's Tech Start-Up Scene Comes of Age
summary: Over the last decade, New York has been building a real tech center, where software, media, and ad-related startups are thriving, a venture capital community is growing and serial entrepreneurs are commonplace.

headline: Japanese Yields Hit Two-Month High
summary: Japanese government bond yields hit their highest level in nearly two months, a sharp turnaround from the seven-year lows reached in late August.

headline: NAIC Picks BlackRock to Evaluate CMBS
summary: The NAIC has selected BlackRock to assist in assessing commercial mortgage-backed securities, as state regulators reduce their reliance on the major ratings firms in determining how much capital insurers must hold to back up investments.

headline: Shiite Pakistanis Targeted in Bombing
summary: Dozens of people were killed when an explosion struck a religious minority procession in Quetta, Pakistan, whose members were calling for solidarity with Palestinians.

headline: Nigeria Looks to Revive Stock Exchange
summary: Nigeria's financial regulator said that it is looking at allowing foreign stock exchange operators to invest in the Nigerian Stock Exchange as it undergoes privatization, in efforts aimed at reviving the country's capital markets.

headline: Exporters Advance in Tokyo
summary: Japanese stocks closed higher on the back of exporters, starting the month with three straight gains and ending the week up 1.4%.

headline: Japanese Capital Spending Slips
summary: Capital spending by Japanese businesses slipped during the quarter ended June, but inventory investment surged, suggesting the government will revise upward its GDP growth estimate for the quarter.

headline: Australia Independent Open to Labor
summary: An Australian independent lawmaker signaled he might support Labor, another boost to Prime Minister Julia Gillard entering a crucial weekend of talks to cobble together a government.

headline: Samsung Expects Profit Boost From Mobile Phones
summary: South Korea's Samsung Electronics forecsts a double-digit profit margin from its mobile operations in the third quarter.

headline: U.K. Services Growth Slows
summary: The U.K.'s economic recovery showed further signs of losing steam as data showed a sharp slowdown in growth in the country's dominant services sector.

headline: China to Adjust Price-Index Weighting
summary: China's statistics bureau next year will increase the weight of housing-related items and reduce the weighting of food in its official consumer price index.

headline: A Mother to the Poor
summary: India commemorates Mother Teresa's death anniversary on Sunday. Some snapshots from her life.

headline: Euro-Zone Retail Sales Rise
summary: Retail sales in the 16 countries that use the euro rose more than expected in July in a fresh sign that consumer demand is helping drive economic growth.

headline: Greenland Oil Protest Ends
summary: Cairn Energy said it has restarted operations on the oil drilling rig it has under contract offshore Greenland following the end of a protest by Greenpeace.

summary: Bharti Airtel said Shravin Mittal--son of founder and Chairman Sunil Bharti Mittal--will join as a manager at an overseas unit.

headline: India Food Prices Remain Red-Hot
summary: India's food prices are on the boil again with inflation rising 1.8% in the seven days to Aug. 21, cementing expectations of a fresh round of monetary tightening this month.

headline: Kathakali Dance-Drama
summary: Kathakali is a mix of dance, music and dramatization of stories which are mostly adapted from Indian epics. Some snapshots.

headline: The Queen's Baton's India Journey
summary: The Queen's Baton entered India through the Wagah Border on June 25 and is expected to reach the host city New Delhi by the end of this month. Some snapshots of its journey till now.

headline: TCS Unit Eyes Contracts
summary: Diligenta, a unit of Tata Consultancy Services, has been approached by two prospective clients for outsourcing contracts worth more than £100 million each, a senior executive said.

headline: Africa Dispatch: Building Breezy Home in Ghana Isn't So Easy
summary: Joe Osae-Addo moved back to his native Ghana to build a home for his family. A simple enough idea, except that he wanted to use local timber, local bamboo, and local adobe mud blocks.

summary: In China's insurance companies, the private-equity industry may have found just the kind of partners it has been looking for.

summary: A slim lead helped spark an inquiry that found some of Europe's banks actively evaded U.S. law in aiding sanctioned countries to move $2 billion undetected.

headline: We're Helping Kids to Cut Calories
summary: Our industry understands that obesity is a serious national challenge ("Please Sir, Can I Have a Bit Less?" by Lionel Tiger, op-ed, Aug. 21). That's why we've stepped up to be part of the solution.

headline: From North Korea, Word of Shortages

summary: What tennis commentators say is zooming back to the players at lightening speed, and many don't like what they hear.
